author: ANTHONY KEANE
title: How to teach kids about money and how to start saving
text:
Video Image Make your kids money smart 2:10 David Koch reveals the three financial lessons to teach your children
September 29th 2015 22 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/Lifestyle/ Money matters ... you can teach kids about managing money from a young age.
ANTHONY KEANE TEACHING children about money in a world where traditional ways of making transactions are disappearing quickly is one of the biggest challenges parents face.
But it’s never too soon for parents and even grandparents to help kids learn some valuable financial lessons.
BT Financial Group financial specialist Bryan Ashenden says it’s a good idea to keep things simple, fun and flexible, while Petra Churcher, an ipac financial planner, says the first step for parents is often to recognise their own money flaws.
“Parents are unwittingly teaching their children bad habits through their own habits because many parents don’t have good money skills themselves,” she says.
Here are four ideas to give kids some cash clues.
1. START SPENDING POCKET MONEY
“Make the children responsible for some purchases themselves, so they learn how to spend as well as how to save ,” Churcher says. “A child that saves 100 per cent of their pocket money isn’t really learning anything.”
Weekends and school holidays can be a good time to earn some extra pocket money, and then learn how to budget and spend it on a holiday or excursion.
MONEYSAVERHQ'S GUIDE TO SAVING MONEY
Pocket money should be paid by direct debit rather than cash from age 11. Source: Supplied
2. SET SAVINGS GOALS
“Teach them the difference between a need and a want. Write a list of things the child is responsible for buying, and put a percentage aside for a savings goal,” Churcher says.
“Don’t make the goals too big — make it easy for the child to feel a sense of achievement when they reach it. Children have short attention spans.”
3. THINK BEYOND SAVINGS
Ashenden suggests using money to help children think about others. “Get your kids thinking about how money can make social change and how they may want to contribute to a cause or interest.”
A mini fundraiser among family and friends might be a valuable holiday activity, with the proceeds to go to a charity that the children research.
4. PAY THEM ELECTRONICALLY
We’re quickly heading to a cashless society, so it’s wise to get children used to it.
“The challenge we have is that money in the online world is not real to us,” Churcher says. She says pocket money should be paid by direct debit from about age 11.
